item.description:
NEW HAMPSHIRE SERIES:
Owl's Head

EVENT ORGANIZER: Julie Moran. Please contact me here with your thoughts and ideas about this trip: jmmoran {{AT}} nycap.rr.com, Mobile 281-5882. FINISH YOUR NH 48 4,000 LIST WITH US!


ESSENTIAL TRIP DETAILS:

Difficulty: 17.8 miles, 3,135 Feet total vertical climb. At a 1.5 mile / hour pace this is about a 12-hour hike.

CLICK HERE: Google Maps Trailhead Directions, Distances (link) from the Hancock-Big Rock Campgrounds (where our groups are planning to camp during the weekend) just down the road to the trailhead location at the Lincoln Woods Visitor's Center, about six miles west of Woodstock, NH.

Trailhead Start Time: 7:30 a.m.


The Owl's Head with Bondcliff visible behind it on the left; Mt. Carrigain on the horizon (center); and Mt. Hancock in front of it, to the right.



TRIP SUMMARY / UPDATES (05/12/2010 2:45 p.m.): This trip is a cross-posted weekend camping event with Hudson Valley Hikers (HVH), the New England Hiking Meetup (NEHM) and the 4 Seasons Hiking Group. NOTE: This is a dog-friendly hike (i.e., Mike is coming!).

The NH Trails link below will take you to some very interesting information about the Lincoln Woods Trail, which "follows what was once the main line of the East Branch and Lincoln Railroad (1893-1948) up the East Branch of the Pemigewasset River to Franconia Brook and the boundary of the Congressionally-designated Pemigewasset Wilderness ... one of the easiest backcountry trails in the White Mountain National Forest, as it is wide and straight with little gradient and with all significant stream crossings (having bridges)." You can still see remaining railroad ties -- check out the links to Andrew Lavigne's two trip reports to the area below. The Lincoln Brook Trail is reached from the Lincoln Woods Trail via the Franconia Brook Trail that runs the eastern length of the Owl's Head uplift. The unnamed path referred to as the Owls Head Slide trail leads from the Lincoln Brook Trail to the summit commonly known as Owls Head (the true Owls Head is a bump farther south on the same ridge). The first part of the trail climbs steeply up an old landslide, then the trail climbs steeply in woods before a flatter section to the traditional Owl's Head summit.


A summertime view of the Franconia Brook Trail, from Andrew Lavigne's very excellent website (thanks Andrew). We can do considerably more of this trail if we do this hike as a loop, which would add just a tenth of a mile (but add about 420 feet of climb).



ESSENTIALS TO BRING: Flash light AND head lamp, food / snacks / at least three bottles of water, first aid items, sun screen, bug repellent. Wear multiple layers of synthetic materials for warmth; trekking poles may be helpful gear for this hike.


RESEARCH ESSENTIALS:

CLICK HERE FOR A TRIP PLANNER OF THE HIKE ROUTE -- PRINT AND TAKE A COPY OF BOTH PAGES WITH YOU.

TRAIL DESCRIPTIONS AND TRIP REPORTS
Link, Trail Description -- Lincoln Woods Trail
Link, Trail Description -- The Owl's Head Slide path to the summit ridge
Link, Trail Description -- General discussion of the routes to Owl's Head

Link, Up-To-Date Trail Conditions


INFORMATION LINKS, OWL'S HEAD
Link, SummitPost Page
Link, Hike The Whites Page
Link, New England 4,000 Peak-Bagging Page
Link, Appalachian Mountain Club Page
Link, Trip Report / Summer 2009, Andrew Lavigne (Trip #1)
Link, Trip Report / Summer 2009, Andrew Lavigne (Trip#2)
Link, Wikipedia Page



NOTE: You are responsible for bringing appropriate gear, supplies, clothing, first aid and lights. You should review topographic maps and trail features carefully; understanding topography of any challenge hike is key to your knowing where you are, where you're going and how to get back.

WEATHER AND OTHER SUDDEN EVENTS CAN CAUSE SUDDEN CHANGES TO OR CANCELLATION OF THIS EVENT. YOU MUST CHECK BACK TO THE MEETUP.COM SITE OFTEN.

See you there! Julie.
item.how_to_find_us: Look for the Green Honda Element ...
